results.abstract: Ann Powers reviews Natalie Merchant concert at Neil Simon Theater (M)

headline.main: A Bit of Defiance Amid the Sweetness and Light

results.snippet: ''Outlaw'' is not a term that obviously applies to Natalie Merchant. This 36-year-old singer is no gender-bending blasphemer; most parents probably feel blessed when her soothing alto emanates from their children's bedrooms. Yet from the moment she...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Outlaw'' is not a term that obviously applies to Natalie Merchant. This 36-year-old singer is no gender-bending blasphemer; most parents probably feel blessed when her soothing alto emanates from their children's bedrooms. Yet from the moment she emerged shrouded in a hot-pink veil to begin the second of five concerts at the Neil Simon Theater on Wednesday, Ms. Merchant gave her own definition to defiant artistry. ''People downcast in despair see the disillusion everywhere,'' she intoned in ''Break Your Heart.'' Ms. Merchant has made it her mission to witness and try to change that predicament. Idealism and ultra-sensitivity are her extremes; her opulent music, grounded in her own piano playing, sets the mood for her dramatically empathetic world view. Most of the songs she performed, ranging from her years in the band 10,000 Maniacs to the present, offered compassion or advice.

results.abstract: Committee of former Russian astronauts appeals to Russian public for contributions to save aging and doomed Mir space station, symbol of nation's once-proud space program; Government plans to bring station's last crew back to Earth in Aug and send station to fiery death in Earth's atmosphere sometime in 2000; photo (M)

headline.main: Russian Astronauts Plead With Public to Save the Mir

results.snippet: The Russian Government couldn't do it. A shadowy British entrepreneur couldn't do it.    Now the job of saving Russia's space station Mir -- the aging, and doomed, symbol of a once-proud space program that was the first to send a man into orbit --...
results.lead_paragraph: The Russian Government couldn't do it. A shadowy British entrepreneur couldn't do it. Now the job of saving Russia's space station Mir -- the aging, and doomed, symbol of a once-proud space program that was the first to send a man into orbit -- has been given to the Russian people.

results.abstract: Anita Gates reviews book Back to the Moon by Homer H Hickam Jr (M)
results.snippet: BACK TO THE MOON  By Homer H. Hickam Jr.  447 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $23.95.
results.lead_paragraph: BACK TO THE MOON By Homer H. Hickam Jr. 447 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $23.95.
